stem: The nurse is performing a point-of-care (POC) blood glucose test. Place the steps in the correct order.

options.text: Wipe away the first drop of blood with a sterile gauze pad.
Prick the finger using a sterile lancet.
Apply the second drop of blood to the reagent strip.
Apply pressure to the puncture site.
Cleanse the side of the finger with an alcohol swab and allow to dry.

rationale.correct: Standardized glucose testing ensures accuracy. (1) Cleaning prevents infection. (2) Careful puncture uses the side of the pad (fewer nerves). (3) The first drop contains serous fluid and tissue contaminants that can dilute the result. (4) The second drop is pure capillary blood. (5) Wound care.
rationale.incorrect: Using the first drop of blood is a common error that leads to falsely high or low readings depending on the cleaning agent used.
clinicalPearls: If blood flow is poor, do not 'milk' the finger constantly; instead, have the client dangle their arm or use a warm compress.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember 'Wipe the First, Use the Second'. This is a very common NCLEX skill question.

reviewUnits.heading: Blood Glucose Monitoring Protocols
reviewUnits.body: Nurses verify the meter code matches the strip bottle (if applicable) and monitor for signs of hypoglycemia in diabetic clients.
